title: @Riot Message to Riot regarding crit
body:
In case crit rework is approved for the sake of ranged champion DPS, please persevere crit for melee champions.

Reason being {{champion:23}} {{champion:41}}  & {{champion:157}} are heavily reliant on critting for their playstyles, as well as one of the most awesome AD items in the game  is {{item:3142}}. It should be acceptable for an ADC to decide to opt for a ghostblade, but it shouldn't be better than the %damage amps provided by the reworks.

Keep {{item:3104}} for melee carries and rework {{item:3031}} to be ADC sustained damage amp.

Thank you for your time and your consideration. :)

replies.body: I disagree, crit is rng.  Just make it % autoattack amplification.  You woulnd't even have to change yasuo or trynd's passives or items
RNG IS %AA amp. Once you average it over time. idk y people get so bent out of shape over it.

Because of how it affects success cases, particularly in bot lane. 

A lucky crit in the earlygame can completely shift the entire course of laning phase in the favor of a potentially less-skilled player. Sure, over time, it equals out, I don't think anyone is gonna contest that.

The point is that RNG shouldn't decide laning as heavily as it currently can, not necessarily "RNG IS EVIL". 

Pretend you're in bot lane, playing ADC, in 2 different scenarios(crit vs no crit). Let's assume you get hit 3 times in the first lets say 10 minutes of laning, equaling the same amount of damage in either scenario. 

If you're hit by 3 non-crit autos, you know exactly how much damage you can take, you can still CS and trade, and it doesn't necessarily change the way you approach the lane.

However, if the first of those 3 autos is a crit, you've now taken a large hit to your health, and even if the other 2 autos are non-crits that by themselves do less damage than in the no-crit scenario, you have to play safer. Not only do you not know for sure whether the next autos will be crits or not, you've taken twice the damage for no extra work on the enemy ADC's part,  you have to come out on top during trades to reach equal threat levels with the enemy ADC, and depending on the damage level you might feel the need to (depending on when the damage was received) burn heal or your support might use mana/skills they wouldn't otherwise due to the immediate damage spike.

--------------------

RNG definitely has a place in league, and on paper the numbers are balanced. The issue comes from the negative gameplay experience it causes, particularly in cases where a frontloaded crit in a trade rewards way too much for zero extra work on the "crit-er"s part, even if they sacrifice later damage instances to acquire it.

The "Consistent DPS" versus "Burst Damage" ***is*** a legitimate candidate for debate, as both have their benefits. The problem comes from "Burst Damage" being almost universally the superior option with regards to highly trade-focused lanes like Top and Bot where players are usually playing "Consistent DPS" roles, and that shouldn't be the case as much as it is.

Crit should stay, it should just not *always* be the more powerful option (at least as far as ADCs are concerned). Pure stats say it is not, it's effect on gameplay, laning, and PvP interactions say it is. If nothing else, raw AD should be just as appealing, but IE is such a powerful item right now (as it has been for awhile, since the BT "changes" *cough* nerf *cough*) and gives so much AD that rushing IE is almost always superior except in a few fringe cases.
The lane it affects the most is actually top lane. In bot lane an adc has a support to help them out if a engage goes sour because of a crit.

That'd be true if the first buy for all but 3 top laners was always IE every single game, which I think everyone can agree its not. 

Theoretically, yes, Top would be more affected by crit, but the champions played in top don't itemize for crit nearly as often, so it's affected significantly less.

Meanwhile, in bot lane, if you're playing anyone but Vayne or Ezreal (I'm sure there's at least one more, but i'm not an ADC and don't remember) and not rushing IE, you're screwing yourself over because IE is so much more powerful than anything else.
The biggest offender is trynd. One or two crit and he snowballs out of control. In bot lane you have 2 people so even if something goes south because of a crit you can still come back.

Well yeah, Trynd is a major abuse case.

But Trynd isn't played every game.

That's my point, the cases where Top Laners abuse crit are certainly more problematic, but *as a whole*, it's less impactful in top lane due to the distinct gap in "crit-rushers" in top vs bot lane (since you have an ADC almost every game in bot lane and they're almost invariably rushing IE).

Well that was kind of my point. The abuse cases are few and far between. So instead of trying to dramatically change crit. It might be better to look at the abuse cases.

It is true that adc's use crit. However the IE rush comes and goes based on the strength of Bt, Tri force, and BORK. One of the four is always rushed. Well adc's can occasionally get lucky crits. Usually adc's don't even have any crit until 10-12 minutes in when the laning phase is half-most of the way over. Which is part of the reason it isn't really a problem in bot lane.

In general I don't really get riot's anti-RNG insistence.  If there was no RNG at all then in a fight the winner/loser would be determined by who was already ahead which makes the game dull if you're already behind.

That being said, it seems silly to have crit be the only RNG in the game.  If dodge wasn't good enough because a player can get pissed when their opponent is 1 hit from death and gets a "lucky" dodge, then crit shouldn't be good enough since a player could be 2 hits from death and their opponent gets a "lucky" crit on them.
The winner of a fight should not be determined by who gets lucky, it should be determined by who fights better.

Crit's are very non-interactive because they can't be avoided but they can still change the course of the fight. Imagine instead of being on a set stage the dragon spawned in semi random areas on the map. This would be a source of RNG to the game, but would not make or break fights, and instead would force them in interesting ways.

I believe dodge was removed while Crit wasn't because dodge completely invalidated the time the enemy spent attacking, while crits don't invalidate defenses or enemy attacks. I think that's part of the general reason; that and dodges feel crummy to go up against, and crits can as well, but crits can be countered without a single special item while dodge couldn't (Sword of the Divine was the ONLY dodge counter, if I remember correctly, while ALL armor and attack speed/damage reductions help to counter crit). The problem with having ONLY that one item prevent all dodges, even though it's the same in DotA, is that far fewer champions here could make use of the item (raw attack speed with pretty much no other stat, whereas MKB in DotA has raw damage, a bit of attack speed, and a mini-stun on-hit with more damage and a 35% proc rate, making it fairly reliable), and so it was inefficient to get it since it was only valuable against ONE champion, another difference with DotA, wherein there's a couple champions with dodge straight-up built into their kits, as well as accuracy reductions functioning similarly that MKB also countered. 

In short: Dodge was removed because there was much less counterplay, and it completely invalidated your actions that led up to the dodge, while crit has numerous counters and invalidates nothing.

While I also want crit to go the way of dodge and Phage's RNG slow proc, Riot has yet to say they are actually *going to change it* any time within the next year or more, and this discussion only shows other players also wanting crit gone, not Riot saying they are planning a rework.

While I love the conversations happening here and the varied possibilities of what to do with crit, don't look at this post's score as support, at least 50 points from it have been vote-botted or brigaded. As well as any comments that weren't well liked.

>In case crit rework is approved for the sake of ranged champion DPS,

What exactly do you mean by "for the sake of ranged champion DPS"? A crit rework that derandomized crit wouldn't have to touch their DPS at all. If we changed crit to a %autoattack damage increase, it would have the exact same expected DPS that the current random crits have. Reworking crit could just be for the sake of removing randomness, not hitting damage. What are you trying to say here?

I think the melee champions could be changed pretty easily. Yasuo is reliant on crit, but he isn't reliant on the RNG part of crit. He builds crit just because it is the best DPS steroid for him, not because he is trying to randomly get crits on people. You could change his to a % damage increase model easily without losing any part of his feel and without hurting him at all. Exactly the same DPS, which is all Yasuo cares about.

Similarly, Gangplank pokes with the Q, but he doesn't need to have crit-fishing as a main mechanic. Just increasing the damage of his Q by an equivalent amount to what the expected dps of crit would be plenty, particularly if it happened alongside buffs and changes that he already needs.

Tryndamere is the only one who would really need changes, since he is reliant on the randomness of crit early in the game. Given that he's the only champion in the game who would have a problem, a small redesign to make him fit with a derandomized crit system would be a better solution than preserving items just for him.

I agree, discussion is important.

I don't like or support crit, but I'll use it.  I also don't try and  depend on it to win, and wont pretend that I don't when my team is on a full retreat.  Alternatively, once I finish IE before the other ADC, I get a bitter sweet feeling about winning the lane from that point.  Sure, I can get a few early crits and dictate the lane how I please, but that's not healthy.  Taking support presence out of the equation, if I fall behind and stay behind, unless it's a case of extreme counterpicking, then I can say I'm doing something wrong.

I hate having my trades and duels decided on who can crit more than the other.  I get 3 crits in a row and kill the other guy while he didn't get 1 off on me. Sure that's great and I got 300g, but I don't feel good about how it happened.

I completely agree in that case crit won you that trade without much input/play from your end, and that's an overall bad thing to happen. However, inversely, reliability can work against fair and engaging play as well.

If, say, crit is turned to a raw dmg amp (as is such a popular alternative to mention) you have no method of producing variance yourself. True, it's a team game and you need to also rely on your teammmates as well as your opponents mistakes, but without the *possibility* of a crit, or in other words a 'chaos factor' to consider the game/trading will always come down to momentum. The RNG element that crit brings actually brings more interaction and reactive play than without and imho make the game better.

However I did mention that chain crits, while rare, are an edge case I don't like. As such I'd be fine with something along the lines of a crit internal cooldown to allow the RNG possibility to remain but eliminating the possibility of a crit chain winning the entire lane. There are other suggestions I've seen like changing crits to a utility effect (resource refund, AS/MS buff, etc) among other ideas as well.

Personally I feel the idea of an RNG element isn't the thing people are against, but the simple fact that the crits can be a deciding factor in a lane in edge cases that they've been the unfortunate victim of.
